title: Question 3
prompt: Based on this information and the excerpt from the beginning of the play, how does Nora and Torvald’s relationship change during the play?
description:
Click the one best answer to each question.

Over the course of the play, Torvald learns that Nora has forged a bond and borrowed money to bring Torvald to Italy to save his health. He is horrified at the revelation and condemns her, but when he learns the lender has forgiven Nora and will not reveal her crime, he also forgives Nora. However, Nora will not take his forgiveness. Torvald’s reaction to learning of her crime has destroyed the marriage for Nora. Near the end of the play, Torvald tells Nora, “Let me help you if you are in want.” Nora responds, “No. I can receive nothing from a stranger.”
feedback:
Nora’s reaction to Torvald differs greatly from the scene at the beginning of the play to the end of the play. In the beginning of the play, Nora is affectionate toward Torvald, and she is horrified by the idea of his death. She says, “ Oh! don’t say such horrid things.” When Torvald offers Nora money to please her, Nora’s reaction is pleased: “Money! ” In the end of the play, however, when Torvald offers her help, she rejects him immediately, calling him a stranger. Her perception of Torvald has changed, and so her reaction to Torvald has changed. Nora has moved from being affectionate toward Torvald to feeling as if she doesn’t really know him.


“No. I can receive nothing from a stranger.”
